semantic_title: Selection of First-Listed Diagnosis in Outpatient Settings
section_path: Section IV > A. Selection of first-listed condition

content.full_text: In the outpatient setting, the term first-listed diagnosis is used in lieu of principal diagnosis. In determining the first-listed diagnosis the coding conventions of ICD-10-CM, as well as the general and disease specific guidelines take precedence over the outpatient guidelines. Diagnoses often are not established at the time of the initial encounter/visit. It may take two or more visits before the diagnosis is confirmed. The most critical rule involves beginning the search for the correct code assignment through the Alphabetic Index. Never begin searching initially in the Tabular List as this will lead to coding errors. (Evidence: pg no: 112, L28-L31)
content.summary: Establishes the concept of first-listed diagnosis for outpatient settings and provides fundamental coding search methodology (Evidence: pg no: 112, L28-L31)
key_concepts: First-listed diagnosis replaces principal diagnosis in outpatient settings (Evidence: pg no: 112, L29)
ICD-10-CM conventions take precedence over outpatient guidelines (Evidence: pg no: 112, L29-L30)
Diagnoses may require multiple visits to confirm (Evidence: pg no: 112, L30-L31)
Alphabetic Index must be used first, never start with Tabular List (Evidence: pg no: 112, L31)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Use first-listed diagnosis instead of principal diagnosis in outpatient settings (Evidence: pg no: 112, L29)
detailed_rules.explanation: The terminology differs between inpatient and outpatient settings, with outpatient using first-listed diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 112, L29)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Always begin code search through Alphabetic Index, never start with Tabular List (Evidence: pg no: 112, L31)
detailed_rules.explanation: Starting with Tabular List leads to coding errors, proper methodology requires Alphabetic Index first (Evidence: pg no: 112, L31)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify the condition/reason for encounter
Step 3: Verify code in Tabular List
Step 4: Apply ICD-10-CM conventions and guidelines

references_to.title: Conventions, general coding guidelines and chapter-specific guidelines
references_to.explanation: These guidelines take precedence in outpatient settings

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient presents for initial evaluation of chest pain, diagnosis not yet established
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Chief complaint: Chest pain. Assessment: Chest pain, rule out cardiac cause.
step_by_step: Step 1: Search 'chest pain' in Alphabetic Index

correct_coding.rationale: Symptom code appropriate when diagnosis not established (Evidence: pg no: 112, L30-L31)

Using principal diagnosis terminology in outpatient settings (Evidence: pg no: 112, L29)
tips: Diagnoses may require multiple visits to establish (Evidence: pg no: 112, L30-L31)

clinical_context: Outpatient diagnosis establishment may be progressive over multiple encounters
